metadata.abstractText: Developing reliable methods of constructing cell-free multienzyme biocatalytic systems is a milestone goal of synthetic biology. It would enable overcoming the limitations of current cell-based systems, which su er from the presence of competing pathways, toxicity, and ine cient access to extracellular reactants and removal of products. DNA nanostructures have been suggested as ideal sca olds for assembling sequential enzymatic cascades in close enough proximity to potentially allow for exploiting of channeling e ects; however, initial demonstrations have provided somewhat contradictory results toward con rming this phenomenon. In this work, a three-enzyme sequential cascade was realized by site-speci cally immobilizing DNAconjugated amylase, maltase, and glucokinase on a self-assembled DNA origami triangle. The kinetics of seven di erent enzyme con gurations were evaluated experimentally and compared to simulations of optimized activity. A 30-fold increase in the pathway s kinetic activity was observed for enzymes assembled to the DNA. Detailed kinetic analysis suggests that this catalytic enhancement originated from increased enzyme stability and a localized DNA surface a nity or hydration layer e ect and not from a directed enzyme-to-enzyme channeling mechanism. Nevertheless, the approach used to construct this pathway still shows promise toward improving other more elaborate multienzymatic cascades and could potentially allow for the custom synthesis of complex (bio)molecules that cannot be realized with conventional organic chemistry approaches.
